For the sketch, draw a circle with the center at (0.0221, 0.0221) and a radius of 0.0221 on the X-Y plane. Extrude the sketch by 0 units along the normal and 0.3691 units along the opposite direction of the normal. Apply a scale factor of 0.0713 to the sketch before extrusion. The final shape will be a rectangular metal plate with two circular holes along the Z-axis, where one hole is larger than the other.</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: Three-Dimensional Rectangular Prism Construct a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The sides are parallel and meet at right angles. The dimensions of the prism are 2 units by 3 units by 4 units. Begin by creating a new coordinate system for the base part. Set the euler angles to [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and the translation vector to [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]. Sketching the 2D Profile Now, create a new sketch on the X-Y plane. 1. Draw the first line segment (line\\_1) with the start point at [0.0, 0.0] and the end point at [0.75, 0.0]. 2. Draw the second line segment (line\\_2) with the start point at [0.75, 0.0] and the end point at [0.75, 0.75]. 3. Draw the third line segment (line\\_3) with the start point at [0.75, 0.75] and the end point at [0.0, 0.75]. 4. Draw the fourth line segment (line\\_4) with the start point at [0.0, 0.75] and the end point at [0.0, 0.0]. Scaling the Sketch Scale the 2D sketch using the specified scaling parameter `sketch_scale` from the assembly JSON, which in this case is 0.75. Transforming and Extruding the 2D Profile Next, transform the scaled 2D sketch and rotate it by the euler angles defined in the coordinate system, which are [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]. The translation vector for the coordinate system is also [0.0, 0.0, 0.0], so apply that as well. Extrude the 2D sketch to generate the 3D model. In this case, the `extrude_depth_towards_normal` is 0.75, and `extrude_depth_opposite_normal` is 0.0. Consequently, extrude the 2D sketch along the Z-axis by a depth of 0.75 units. Note that the `sketch_scale` was previously applied. Finally complete the boolean operation defined for the part (in this example, `NewBodyFeatureOperation` is used) and the first intermediate CAD model, or part\\_1, is now complete.</description>
